title: Stevie Wonder serenades Will Smith with Happy Birthday during Hustlers screening
text:
Stevie Wonder made an unexpected appearance at a birthday celebration held for Will Smith.

The Gemini Man star, 51, shared the clip on Instagram Tuesday, taken last month at a celebration for Smith's September 25 birthday.

Smith and friends took in a screening of the new Jennifer Lopez film Hustlers, paving a path for the music icon, 69, to make a timely cameo.

And many more: Stevie Wonder, 69, made an unexpected appearance at a birthday celebration held for Will Smith's September 25 birthday in a clip the Gemini Man star shared on social media Tuesday

Smith tagged Lopez into the Instagram post, in which he and the Superstition singer were in great spirits inside a movie theater, with her image on the screen.

'So Jennifer, this is crazy ... it's a really weird story,' said Smith. 'It's my birthday, and we're in the movie theater, and it's the scene where your character is talking about, "Stevie Wonder was in the champagne room."'

Smith said that at that point, the film was paused, and Wonder emerged to sing his 1981 song Happy Birthday.

'Stevie walks in and sings me Happy Birthday!' Smith said. 'So we just wanted to send this to you!'

Special occasion: Smith and friends took in a screening of the new Jennifer Lopez film Hustlers, paving a path for the music icon, 69, to make a timely cameo

Good timing: Wonder entered the room when Lopez mentioned him in the movie

Excited: Will said in the clip to Jennifer Lopez, 'Stevie walks in and sings me Happy Birthday! So we just wanted to send this to you!'

In the clip, Wonder was clad in an all-black ensemble with sunglasses, while Smith wore a white polo shirt with a black ball cap and black pants.

Wonder released the song in September of 1980 off of his album Hotter Than July. He initially wrote the song three years earlier in support of a holiday in honor of Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, according to Rolling Stone.

The lyrics included: 'You know it doesn't make much sense/There ought to be a law against anyone who takes offense/At a day in your celebration.'

Classic tune: Wonder released the song in September of 1980 off of his album Hotter Than July

Cultural icon: Wonder initially wrote the song in 1977 in support of a holiday in honor of Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, which was signed into law in 1983 and observed in 1986

Wonder headlined a rally in Washington D.C. in January of 1981 in support of the national holiday in the civil right's leader's memory.

The holiday was signed into law by President Ronald Reagan in 1983 and observed three years later in 1986.

That January, Wonder was lauded for his performance on a special called An All-Star Celebration Honoring Martin Luther King Jr. that featured entertainment legends including Diana Ross, Eddie Murphy, Bob Dylan, and Quincy Jones.
